title.value: A Conceptual Framework for Representing Events Under Public Health Surveillance
title.justification: The title concisely indicates the main focus and contribution of the paper, which is proposing a conceptual framework for event representation in the context of public health surveillance.
title.quote: A Conceptual Framework for Representing Events Under Public Health Surveillance

extractions.description: The paper addresses the challenge of information integration across event-based surveillance (EBS) systems by proposing a candidate conceptual framework for representing events and related concepts in public health surveillance, aiming to achieve semantic interoperability among different systems.

type.justification: The paper proposes a conceptual framework and is focused on defining and clarifying relationships among concepts within EBS systems, indicating a theoretical approach.
type.quote: We aim to address this gap by proposing a candidate conceptual framework for representing events and related concepts in the domain of public health surveillance.

name.justification: The paper's focus is explicitly on improving global disease surveillance through event-based systems, which is a subfield of public health.
name.quote: We aim to address this gap by proposing a candidate conceptual framework for representing events and related concepts in the domain of public health surveillance.

name.justification: The paper discusses semantic interoperability extensively as it aims to align key concepts across multiple EBS systems for better integration.
name.quote: Reaching consensus regarding these high-level concepts should create a foundation for achieving semantic interoperability amongst systems, improving global EBS.

name.justification: The paper involves conceptual modelling by proposing a framework to represent events in EBS systems.
name.quote: We aim to address this gap by proposing a candidate conceptual framework for representing events and related concepts in the domain of public health surveillance.
